task_summary: Push a T-shaped block into the target outline, then safely disengage the end-effector, following the typical two-stage Real-World Push-T protocol on a UR5 setup at around 10 Hz control/observation cadence. [web:16][web:17][web:7]

task_long_description.overview: The scene shows a UR-series arm with a round pusher interacting with a red T-shaped block on a tabletop and a faint target outline, which matches the Real-World Push‑T task definition. The goal is to make stable contact, align the T block with the goal region, and execute short corrective pushes until the T is fully within the target before retreating to avoid occlusion or perturbation. The literature describes this as a multi-stage push followed by an end-effector move-away, commonly run near 10 Hz command/update rates. [web:16][web:17][web:7]
preconditions: Robot and camera calibrated for tabletop Push‑T station with visible target outline. [web:16][web:17]
End-effector configured as a round pusher and safe heights defined. [web:16]
Perception can localize T block and goal outline with sufficient accuracy for closed-loop corrections. [web:16][web:17]
Control loop operating near 10 Hz as reported in prior setups. [web:7]
stepwise_plan: Detect or scan to localize the T block and the goal region on the table. [web:16][web:17]
Approach above the block, set yaw, align laterally, and lower until gentle contact is detected. [web:16][web:17]
Execute short directional pushes with intermittent re-alignment to progressively seat the T inside the goal outline. [web:16][web:17]
Verify final alignment relative to the goal and then retreat the tool to a safe end-zone to avoid occlusion. [web:16][web:17]
success_criteria: T block’s footprint fully lies within the goal outline at episode end, consistent with Push‑T evaluation. [web:17][web:16]
Robot retreats without disturbing the final placement, matching the end-zone behavior. [web:17]
No collisions with fixtures and no loss of visual tracking during final verification. [web:16]
failure_and_recovery: Loss of visual tracking or partial occlusion during approach; recover by rescanning in a spiral pattern. [web:16]
Under/over-shoot during pushing due to multimodality near stage transitions; recover by re-aligning and issuing shorter pushes. [web:17]
Premature retreat before full placement; detect misalignment and resume corrective pushes before termination. [web:17]
task_long_description.termination: Stop when the T is within the goal region and the tool has retreated to a safe end-zone or when allotted attempts/time are exceeded per task policy. [web:16][web:17]

frame_3.now_evidence: first stable contact and alignment cue visible [web:16][web:17]
frame_3.predicts_next: push actuation expected; confirms goal direction [web:16][web:17]

task_instruction: The task requires pushing a T-shaped block (gray) to a fixed target (green) with a circular end-effector (blue). Both observation and control frequencies are 10Hz.

node_specs.description: Checks if the T block is already visible to avoid unnecessary scanning. [web:16]
Spiral scan to locate the T block if not immediately visible. [web:16]
Detects the goal outline for alignment and final verification. [web:16][web:17]
Moves above the block to a safe approach height. [web:16]
Sets tool yaw for pushing along the chosen table axis. [web:16]
Lateral micro-alignment before contact to ensure controlled pushing. [web:17]
Descends slowly until contact is detected to establish a stable push. [web:16]
Executes a short push stroke; repeated with re-alignment as needed. [web:17]
Final alignment check relative to the goal outline before retreat. [web:17]
Backs off to a safe end-zone to prevent occlusion or disturbance. [web:17]
Short dwell to allow any residual motion to settle after placement. [web:16]

failure_modes: Losing visibility during transition between stages due to occlusion or ambiguous cues. [web:17]
Overshoot or drift when switching from approach to push because of task multimodality. [web:17]
Premature retreat causing the block to be slightly out of the goal outline. [web:17]
recovery_strategy: Fallback to spiral scan when visibility is lost and retry alignment. [web:16]
Issue shorter pushes with re-alignment cycles until the T fully seats in the goal. [web:17]
If final check fails, re-enter corrective push loop before termination. [web:17]
assumptions: Frames show a red T block while instruction says gray; treated as the same object consistent with Push‑T visual conventions. [web:16]
End-effector appears as a round pusher consistent with the Real‑World Push‑T setup. [web:16]
Reported command/observation rate around 10 Hz is consistent with prior work noting 10 Hz policy outputs. [web:7]

expected_success_criteria: T block inside goal outline with end-effector retreated at episode end. [web:16][web:17]
test_scenarios: grasp_fail (not applicable; replaced by push-contact failure) [web:17]
